What do you do when your RAG application plateaus?

What do you do when your RAG application plateaus?

Instead of using a bigger (and more expensive) model, try this.

Most RAG apps use vector search to match queries to knowledge base items based on semantic similarity.

A problem with this, however, is that just because a query and item are semantically similar, it doesn't necessarily mean the item is *helpful* in answering the user's request.

One way to solve this problem is through fine-tuning.

Fine-tuning an embedding model involves training it on pairs of questions and their appropriate answers. 

The key approach for doing this is contrastive learning, which teaches the model to distinguish between helpful and unhelpful results by minimizing the distance between relevant pair embeddings (while maximizing the distance between irrelevant pair embeddings).

I walk through a concrete example of this (with code) where I fine-tune an embedding model based on AI job posts.

👉 You can read the full blog post here: https://lnkd.in/g6ZtKVyc

Getting a Data Science job was hard until I did these 5 things 👇

Getting a Data Science job was hard until I did these 5 things 👇 

1) Focused my resume: removed details and skills that were irrelevant to a data science job description 

2) Real-world projects: joined a university research group and started taking freelance gigs on Upwork. 

3) Made a portfolio: it doesn’t matter how great your past projects were if no one knows about them. Making a website portfolio is an easy way to showcase your skills and stand out. 

4) Stayed out of the weeds: a big mistake I made in early job interviews was diving into technical details when discussing projects. A better approach is to give a high-level story and go into detail if people ask. 

5) Be yourself: this way, you can get a realistic sense of whether the role is a good fit.

AI Roadmap for Entrepreneurs 👇

AI Roadmap for Entrepreneurs 👇 

The 5 things you need to know to build your next AI app...

1) Use AI Tools

Moving fast means you make mistakes faster than your competition and ship something before you run out of runway.

Tools like ChatGPT, Claude, Cursor, etc., are the best way to do that when it comes to learning and building.

2) Prompt Engineering

Learning how to write effective prompts not only helps you use AI tools better but also allows you to build better LLM systems.

There are a few universal tips you should know (e.g., give details, use structure, give examples), as well as model-specific ones you can find from the particular model provider.

3) RAG

While prompting alone can take you far, it falls short when your solution relies on specialized or user-specific information.

Having a basic understanding of retrieval (i.e. search) and how you can use it to improve LLM responses is central.

4) Tool-use & AI agents

We often don’t just want LLMs to process information for us; we want them to solve our problems.

This is where endowing models with the ability to perform actions (through tool use) helps.

5) Fine-tuning

Some use cases require changing an LLM’s behavior significantly. If prompting and other workarounds are not enough, fine-tuning is a viable option.

Additionally, this allows you to build specialized models for your specific use case, which can come with significant cost savings.


What would you add to this list?

--
If this post was helpful, repost it and follow me (Shaw Talebi) for more :)

5 AI Project Ideas For People in a Hurry…

5 AI Project Ideas For People in a Hurry… 

i.e. no training data required 👇 

1) YouTube Video Summarizer

Use the youtube-transcript-api Python library to extract video transcripts then send them to OpenAI's API to generate summaries.

2) Spam Detection with GPT-4o 

Rather than curating spam/not spam emails, simply craft a prompt for GPT-4o to take email data and return a 0 or 1 label via OpenAI's API.

3) Local Image QA Chatbot

Use Ollama and Gradio to spin up a local chat UI that lets you upload images and ask questions about them.

4) 0-shot Resume Classification

Given a set of labels e.g. "Data Scientist" and "ML Engineer", translate your resume and each label into vectors using an embedding model, then generate a classification based on similarity scores.

5) 0-shot Image Classification 

Basically idea 4, but swap out resumes for images and use a multimodal embedding model like CLIP.

-- 
Let me know if you want me to break any of these down in the comments :)

This quarter, I am doubling down on building products.

This quarter, I am doubling down on building products.

While I'm still a total noob, here are the 5 key principles guiding my product development...

​1) Optimize for speed (move fast)

​As a recovering technical person, my favorite part of building is experimenting with new tools and technologies.

​While this is a lot of fun, it can lead to over-sophisticated products, which crumble when deployed into the wild. Speed allows me to iterate faster and get more shots on goal.

2) Moving fast ≠ rushing

The key point here is using speed as a forcing function for simplicity (i.e. "moving fast").

Rather than asking, "Can I get it done?" asking... "How could I get it done?

​3) Ship monthly

​To make principles 1 and 2 concrete, I'll be time-boxing my development window to just 1 month.

​This gives a clear constraint to drive creativity and action.

​4) Problems are a good thing

​One hesitation for aggressive timelines is worrying about something breaking.

​But this isn't helpful for two reasons... 1) if something breaks, that means people are actually using the product, and 2) every problem (once resolved) leads to a better product.

​5) Solve your own problems

​Product development is about two things: pain points and customers.

​To simplify this for myself, I'm going to focus on my own pain points (thus, pain points for people like me).

This not only allows me to move faster, but if the product fails, I can still get value from it personally :)

10 AI Terms Explained in Plain English 👇

10 AI Terms Explained in Plain English 👇 

AI newcomers are welcomed to the field with a firehose of technical jargon.

However, you don’t need a PhD to wrap your head around AI.

I recently came across Greg Ceccarelli and Hamel H.'s amazing “Glossary of AI Terms” in language anyone can understand.

Here are a handful of my favorite definitions…

1) Agents = AI models that can perform tasks or run code without human help.
2) RAG = Providing relevant context to the LLM.
3) Vector DB = A special database for storing and searching embeddings.
4) Embeddings = Turning words into numbers that show meaning.
5) Hybrid Search = Combining search methods to get better results.
6) Reranking = Sorting results to pick the most important ones.
7) Fine-tuning = Adjusting a pre-trained model for a specific job.
8) RLHF = Training AI using people’s feedback.
9) Multimodal = Models that handle different data types like text and images.
10) Prompt Injection = A security risk where bad instructions are added to prompts.

👉 Link to complete list: https://lnkd.in/gF3DZg9Y

Although the idea of project management might cure insomnia for some data scientists, the more I do projects as an independent, the more I see its value.

Although the idea of project management might cure insomnia for some data scientists, the more I do projects as an independent, the more I see its value. 

This has led me to develop a 5-step project management framework for data science 👇

📌 Phase 0: Problem Definition & Scoping—Formulate the business problem. Design the data science solution. Define project milestones, tasks, and success metrics.

📌 Phase 1: Data Acquisition, Exploration, & Preparation—Evaluate available data. Acquire and explore data. Develop data pipelines. 

📌 Phase 2: Solution Development—Develop ML solution. Evaluate solution validity and value. Iterate with stakeholders and revisit past phases as needed 

📌 Phase 3: Solution Deployment—Integrate solution into real-world business context. Develop solution monitoring pipeline. 

📌 Phase 4: Evaluation & Documentation—Evaluate project outcomes, deliver technical documentation and user guides, and reflect on lessons learned and future work. 

👉 Anything missing here?

I recently had a change in perspective regarding “prompting engineering” for large language models (LLMs) 👀

I recently had a change in perspective regarding “prompting engineering” for large language models (LLMs) 👀 

As a data scientist, I was biased toward building (or fine-tuning) LLMs and didn’t view prompt engineering as something with a whole lot of value 🙄 

But my view has changed on this. 

After running through the new DeepLearning.AI Prompt Engineering course, I realized you can get remarkably far from “just” how you prompt an LLM 

Now I feel many LLM applications can get pretty close to something useful via prompt engineering i.e. no fine-tuning necessary 😮 

And given the orders of magnitude difference in effort to write a prompt vs fine-tune a model, this is probably the best place to start for almost all use cases. 

🤔 What do you think? When does prompt engineering vs fine-tuning make sense?

AI Agents present a new way of thinking about software...

AI Agents present a new way of thinking about software...

Rather than explicitly defining rules and business logic, agents involve giving LLMs the tools they need to solve problems.

For example, instead of developing a rule-based customer support bot, you might give an LLM... 

1. Context about your company
2. A search tool for support docs
3. The ability to escalate issues

With today's powerful LLMs fine-tuned for function calling, such a naive system can get you much of the way there out of the box.

In a new blog post, I explain how LLM tool-use works under the hood and build a simple YouTube video agent using OpenAI's new Agents SDK.

4 Stats Concepts That Rewired My Brain 🧠

4 Stats Concepts That Rewired My Brain 🧠 

If you want to understand how our (messy) world works, then you need to think statistically.

Here are the ideas that have helped me think more clearly…

1) Distributions

While it’s easy to wrap our heads around summary stats like mean, median, variance, etc., they don’t always tell the whole story.

Behind every summary stat is a whole distribution of numbers. Picturing this every time I see a summary stat helped me have a better understanding of reality.

2) Conditional Probabilities

Once I imagine a distribution in my head, it’s important to understand how this distribution will change in light of new evidence.

For example, the probability a business survives 4 more years is 54%, however, if the business has been around for a year, this probability jumps to 62%

3) Expectation Values

Probabilities help us make decisions under uncertainty, but they are not the only thing that matters. You also need to consider potential upside and downside.

For example, even if a new business venture has a 10% chance of success, if success means $10M in profit, it still makes sense to pursue it.

4) Fat Tails

While the majority of stats we learn in school center around the normal distribution (i.e., bell curve), many things follow a different distribution—a Pareto (i.e., 80-20 rule).

Normal distributions focus on the typical. However, it is often the atypical, rare event that makes an impact e.g. 1% of customers can make up 50% of sales!


What are some stats concepts that shaped your thinking?

80% of people are NOT passionate about their job.

80% of people are NOT passionate about their job.

Here’s the mental checklist I used to quit my job (to become an entrepreneur).

1) I want to work for myself

No point in becoming self-employed if it’s not something you want for yourself.

2) I value freedom more than security

The uncertainty of entreprenuership is probably what holds most people back.

However, this uncertainty is the cost of freedom, which is a trade some are willing to make.

3) I value growth more than comfort

This was the central reason I quit my job. I felt I was getting to comfortable in my FT role.

While this might sound like a good thing, it often means you are leaving potential on the table.

4) Status (and other peoples’s opinions of me) aren’t more important to me than my goals

Humans are hard-wired to care about status, which is another major deterrent for aspiring entrepreneurs.

Lucky for me, I’ve sort of always been a weirdo, so I’m used to ignoring what people think of me :P

5) I had made money doing something that wasn’t a job (e.g. freelance and content creation)

What gave me the confidence to think I could survive on my own was that I had previously generated income doing freelance work and content creation.

This is why I think having a “side-hustle” is a critical prerequisite to quitting a job.

6) I have 1 year of runway in savings

Realistically, in the first 1-2 years of entrepreneurship you will work 2X and make 1/2 as much as your FT role.

Having runway gives you more time to build momentum and ultimately allows you to make bigger bets.

--

One of my favorite machine learning techniques is the decision tree 🌲 

They’re intuitive and can be easy to interpret.

However, decision trees notoriously suffer from the overfitting problem ❌ 

This is when an ML model “over-optimizes” to a particular training dataset and has lousy performance on new data. 

A great solution to this problem is a decision tree ensemble 🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲 

This a model that combines the predictions of multiple decision trees instead of merely relying on one. 

🌲 < 🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲🌲

👉 No more overfitting (for the most part) 

👉 More robust importance rankings

Hot take—Don’t study generative AI 🔥

Hot take—Don’t study generative AI 🔥

Those early in their career have asked me, “What’s the best degree for breaking into AI?” 🤔

While I don’t think there is a “best” path that works for everyone, there are more fragile paths than others. 

Here’s my rule of thumb—when trying to establish foundational knowledge, the older the subject, the better 📕>📱

This is based on something called the Lindy Principle, which says the “life expectancy” of a field is proportional to its current age. 

For example—math has been around for ~5,000 years, so Lindy says it’ll be around for a few more millennia 🤓

Conversely, ”Generative AI” has been around for ~1 year, so odds are it’ll be around for another year or so 🤖

There are 2 types of data that every data scientist needs to know about.

There are 2 types of data that every data scientist needs to know about. 

These are what author Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls Mediocristan and Extremistan. 

Mediocristan is the land of Gaussian-like things 🔔 

This type of data has the property that no single observation will significantly impact the aggregate statistics e.g. weight, height, test scores. 

The other type of data is from Extremistan, which is the land of power laws (i.e. a Pareto distribution) 🙅 

In contrast to Mediocrostan, in Extremistan, a single observation can (and often will) drive the aggregate statistics e.g. wealth, sales, pandemics. 

This map visualizes different distributions across this conceptual landscape 👇

2025 is said to be “the year of AI agents”

2025 is said to be “the year of AI agents”

However, no one seems to agree on a single definition for these systems.

Here’s my explanation of AI agents (without the hype)…

Since people can’t agree on a single definition of an AI agent, most practitioners talk about agentic systems instead.

In other words, thinking about agents on a spectrum of agency, ranging from no agency (e.g. rule-based system) to human-level agency.

Here are some examples of that.

Level 1: LLM + Tools 🤖🪛 

Giving LLMs access to tools like a code interpreter, web search, or retrieval system allows them to gather information from the real world and perform actions in it.

Level 2: LLM Workflows 🤖 ➡️ 🤖🪛 

While giving an LLM tools makes it practical, it is still limited because it is forced to perform tasks in a one-shot fashion.

We can overcome this by orchestrating several software components (code or LLM) to accomplish complex tasks.

Level 3: LLM in a Loop 🤖🔄 

Some tasks may not be predictable enough to solve with a pre-defined workflow (even with LLMs).

This is where looping LLM calls can be powerful. This basic flow goes like this.

Generate response from LLM → Evaluate response → if task is complete stop; else add feedback to context and call LLM

If you want to build a great business, you need to build great systems, and who better to learn from than the master system builder—Mother Nature 🌱 

Here are 7 Lessons from Nature for Building Better Systems👇 

1. Diversity — monocultures amplify vulnerabilities and weaknesses. 

2. Redundancy — have 2 lungs in case one fails. 

3. Degeneracy — have 2 modules with overlapping functions e.g. you can breathe through your mouth and nose (i.e. diversity + redundancy). 

4. Recycle (everything) — the waste of one is the fuel of another. 

5. Iteration — iteration beats intelligence e.g. it took an army of PhDs to keep up with COVID mutations. 

6. Hierarchical structures — designs span multiple scales e.g. atoms make up molecules, molecules make cells, cells make tissues, tissues make organs, and organs make organisms. 

7. Symmetry  — the left side looks like the right side. today looks like yesterday. the big looks like the small. (special cases: self-similarity and fractals)

Step 3: Build an LLM Automation

Step 4: Build an ML Project

Once I've done a couple of basic projects, I'd turn to something more advanced.

For example, I might cluster the 100s of research papers on my desktop using text embeddings and a traditional ML algorithm like KMeans.

Step 5: Build a Real-world Project

While personal projects are a great way to learn, they often lack the constraints and challenges of real-world ones.

This is why I'd seek out a problem to solve. 

I'd do this by looking for an internship, joining a research group at my university, or (if I'm really confident) seek out freelance work on Upwork 😎
